oai_dc:dc.dc:title: PREDICTION OF CORE STONE DAMAGE THROUGH THINNED ARMOR LAYER
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Strazzella, Michele
Kobayashi, Nobuhisa
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The stability of rock armor layers has been investigated extensively, but the stability of underlayer and core stones underneath the damaged and thinned armor layer has not been measured experimentally. Strazzella and Kobayashi (2022) conducted an experiment in a wave flume to measure the remaining capacity of low-crested rubble mounds damaged by breaking waves in the surf zone. A mound of a double armor layer on smaller core stones was exposed to irregular wave action lasting 22.2 hours. The core stone was visible through the thinned armor layer but remained in place. The mound with a single armor layer was damaged progressively because of core stone removal after 7.8 hours. These long-duration tests are useful for understanding the core stone damage process. A numerical model is developed to predict the progression of the armor layer damage and core stone removal.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Coastal Engineering Proceedings; No. 38 (2024): Proceedings of 38th Conference on Coastal Engineering, Rome, Italy, 2024; structures.5
